items.content_html:
Fixes #2692.

As far as I can tell there are 7 pages that need updating here:

  • Beacon API:

    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Beacon_API
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Beacon_API/Using_the_Beacon_API
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator/sendBeacon

  • Events:

    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/visibilitychange_event
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/beforeunload_event
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/pagehide_event
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/unload_event

Beacon API

Here I think there are a couple of things to emphasise, which are quite independent:

  • why people should use the Beacon API for analytics, rather than XHR: because it enables reliable delivery of the data without resorting to hacks that hurt performance
  • which events people should use if they want to send analytics at the end of a user's session (without implying that this is the only use case for the Beacon API, as Krinkle notes in the issue). Basically: use visibilitychange, or pagehide if the browsers you are targeting don't support visibilitychange.

The main problem here is that we have three pages describing just one method. This is because for our APIs we have an overview page, and a "Using..." page, and a page for each API method. That makes sense for bigger APIs but for this it makes it impossible not to duplicate guidance, I really don't want to do that, because it will get updated in one page and not the other, then our docs will be inconsistent and misleading.

So what I've tried here is:

  • make the overview page pretty minimal,
  • delete "Using the Beacon API" and make it redirect to the overview page,
  • keep all the details in the sendBeacon() page. The big change here is a new "Sending analytics at the end of a session" section. Note that although I've listed pagehide as a fallback. I've not explicitly called out Safari here, because I think we should keep compat info in the compat section, or it'll get out of date. Note also that the Safari bug seems to be fixed (https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=151234) although I don't know which release it's in - it doesn't seem to be in my 14.0.3.

I'm not sure if deleting "Using the Beacon API" worked properly :/. I used this command:

yarn tool delete /Web/API/Beacon_API/Using_the_Beacon_API --redirect /en-US/docs/Web/API/Beacon_API

...but when I try to load "Using the Beacon API" in my local Yari I get:

...but if I click that "Try reloading the page" link, the "Beacon API" appears as expected. I'm kinda hoping this is some kind of local caching issue, but if you see it as well we'll need to address that.

Page Lifecycle

I updated all four relevant pages:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/visibilitychange_event
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/beforeunload_event
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/pagehide_event
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/unload_event

...mostly by adding "Usage notes" sections, which seems to be a fairly conventional way to include this kind of stuff in event pages. I wonder if we should explicitly deprecate unload though, since the guidance here is "don't use it, no exceptions".
items.title: Fix Beacon API and page lifecycle event guidance

items.content_html:
Updates the list of properties that are forced.

Adds guidance around system color usage and the fact that they are respected in forced colors mode.

Explains that forced colors are chosen based on element, not role.

Adds an example of using a system color (previous example wouldn't have worked without forced-color-adjust: none).
items.title: Update documentation for forced colors mode

items.content_html:
This corresponds to fix mdn/django-locallibrary-tutorial#89

Basically this should not be needed because it should not be possible to get to a state where a bookinstance has no book. Django don't believe that though, so makemigrations fails. This fix just captures what you need to do to get this to work.
items.title: Fix Django BookInstance.book model to have null default value

items.content_html:
This change updates the RegExp article to correct a misclassification of lastIndex as a static property; it’s not a static property, but instead an instance property.

However, it’s not a property of RegExp.prototype but instead is only exposed from RegExp instances — so this change adds some special-casing for that in the article for lastIndex itself, as well as in the RegExp article.

Fixes #2708
items.title: Clarify that lastIndex is RegExp instance property, not a static property

items.content_html:
I was searching myself crazy on how to set the resolution and frame rate, and even thought that it's impossible to control,
until I found that they are set in getUserMedia().
Make a note where this is set, to save others the headache.
items.title: Show how to set resolution and frame rate
